reviewText: "Sanchin Kata: Traditional Training for Karate Power" with Kris Wilder is a DVD that compliments Wilder's book, "The Way of Sanchin Kata."  The DVD is an exceptional resource for anyone who practices the "Three Battles Sequence" or wants to more about this ancient form.  Additionally, many of the concepts Wilder explains and discusses can apply to other martial arts and improve anyone's training.The DVD starts with an introduction that shows Wilder doing the Sanchin Kata in a peaceful wooded area, while you here some of his philosophy regarding training on a voice over.  The wisdom Wilder shares in the nearly eight minute introduction is applicable to all martial artists, not just those who study Karate and the Sanchin Kata.Next, Wilder performs the kata in a dojo setting.  He then very quickly explains some of the history of the kata and how there are different histories depending on the style.  But he stresses that the underlying principles are the same.Wilder then starts teaching principles found in the kata so you can maximize your learning and training.  He starts with the feet and creating a proper foundation.  By bringing out a student, Wilder is able to actually explain and point out the concepts he discusses.  And explain he does!  This is not just a "here's the form, do as I do" type DVD.  I was very impressed with the way Wilder explains things and the reasons behind what he is demonstrating or having his student demonstrate.Wilder moves up the body and discusses the thighs, hips, sacrum, spine, torso, shoulders, arms just as he discussed the feet, ankles, and base.  Kata, or forms, can be an excellent way to learn motion and posture, but only if you practice correct motion and posture.  Wilder does an excellent job of describing proper posture so you can practice with correct alignment, which is needed for generating power within all your movements.After Wilder discusses alignment, he goes on to assist with breathing, punching (I really liked the manila folder drill), and a review as he does a full body audit of his student's stance and position.  During this audit, Wilder provides a great explanation of what instructors are looking for when you see them hitting students during testing, and Wilder explains that you don't have to pound on a student to discern if the student is performing it proper or not.  Finally, Wilder discusses placement of the head.After the explanations of the body alignment and position, Wilder has a short segment on Applications.  He does not provide a series of applications, but rather looks at them globally.  I really liked how he explained the concepts are important and that you can apply the principles of Sanchin to other forms to assist with power generation.The DVD is professionally filmed with good sound, lighting and views.  The DVD has clear chapters so you can review the section you wish to practice, and there are the standard YMAA extras.  The entire program is just under one hour, but contains a wealth of information to maximize your training.The program ends with Wilder performing the kata in a wooded area and then the credits roll.  Please note, this DVD's purpose is not to teach you how to perform the Sanchin Kata.  You will need another resource, or preferably a live instructor, for that.  What this DVD will provide is excellent instruction on how to make your performance and training with this kata better.  I strongly recommend this DVD to anyone who wants to take their Sanchin Kata to a higher level.Reviewed by Alain Burrese, J.D., author of the Lock On Joint Locking Essentials series.
summary: Excellent Instruction to Take Your Kata to a Higher Level
Title: N/A

reviewText: Pleasantly surprised: very well made DVD and good coverage of the Kata.This DVD was very well filmed and the menus are very well made.The emphasis on this short Kata is on getting the form exactly right to be able maximize energy and force for applications.  While applications are not really covered, positioning of the body is covered in great detail.  And thus once one learns this Kata with emphasis on form one will be much better at learning the next Kata which could be learned for application.  So this Kata is learned to learn how to correctly position the body, while other Katas are learned for applications.Kris Wilder works with a student who he has go through the Kata while Wilder explains in great detail how to position the body.For example he goes into detail on how to position the foot: Should it point out to the right, to the left, or to center?  And what is center, aligned with the big toe or the center of the foot.  And he explains the reasons for the alignment of the foot.And from there he works his way up the body to the wrist, hands, and neck and head.Watching this DVD will help you think more constructively about your styles' Kata or form--no matter which style you practice.
summary: Pleasantly surprised: very well made DVD and good coverage of the Kata
Title: N/A

reviewText: I may have accidentally reviewed Kris Wilder's book by the same title here but the same message holds true. The DVD is packed with a great deal of information from the history of the kata to how to better understand were your weaknesses may lie in performing powerful katas. As within his book, Kris breaks down the kata, body part by part and explains how to make the move more powerful and controlled. It is a great supplement to his book for better understanding, or as a stand alone product, You will not be disappointed with this purchase. It will have you thinking more about how you move and better be able to administer more productive and powerful katas.

reviewText: This easy to follow video is full of information, and keeps the format simple, easy to understand, and follow. I learned everything I now know about the Sanchin Kata from this video. The scenery is elegant, and the lesson informal. This Video goes over the basics, the History, as well as fundamentals for body protection. I would refer this to anyone who is interested in A easy to learn Kata with allot of windows for life application's.

reviewText: Although I only have experience with Taekwondo and TaiChi, I found this DVD to be very informative! The specific information is directed towards the Sanchin form, but I was able to apply much of what I learned to my own practice. The comprehensive details related to correct posture and form structure made me think deeply about how I execute the forms I have been taught.Additionally, Kris Wilder offers insights into the philosophical value of the Sanchin form which is also quite interesting.
summary: Applicable to many martial art forms
Title: N/A

reviewText: Last summer, I had the pleasure of training with Sensei Kris Wilder.  The first half of his seminar covered much of the information contained in this video, and I can vouch for its efficacy.  For starters, Sensei Wilder hits hard.  Getting punched by him (at less than full power and through a thick phone book) could best be described as having a bomb go off in your chest.  Clearly, this is a man who knows what he is doing.  However, the great thing is that the skills he uses to create that level of power are replicable.  Having incorporated what Sensei Wilder taught into my training and classes in the months since the seminar, I have noticed a significant increase in the power of my striking techniques.  And I am not alone.  All of my senior students have similarly seen improvement in their karate, which they directly attribute to Sensei Wilder's structure work.  As a result, I am convinced that if a student puts in the time and effort with the material contained in this video, he or she will see marked improvement in his or her techniques.Now, with regard to the specific content of the video, the focus of the film is strictly on the structure of the stance sanchin dachi.  Although Sanchin Kata is demonstrated several times during the introduction and conclusion of the video, there is no instruction on the outward details of the form.  Based on the introduction to the video (which is an excellent piece in and of itself), I believe that this was done purposefully so that the contents of the video could be applied across styles and could be incorporated into whichever form of Sanchin Kata that the viewer practices.  No, instead of teaching the viewer how to do the form in his style, Sensei Wilder teaches how to make whichever version of Sanchin the viewer practices better.  Starting at the feet, he slowly works his way up to the head, providing details and tests that will allow practitioners to develop a strongly stacked structure that is resistant to damage and from which punishing strikes can be delivered.  It's all there.  To my mind, the only thing that is missing is a discussion of the dynamic aspect of sanchin dachi, the half-moon step, a skill that is vital to the application of sanchin dachi in practical situations.  (Note:  The video box states that there is a discussion of the "Crescent Step" in the video.  However, I do not remember such a discussion from my viewing.)It should be noted that this video is a companion piece to Sensei Wilder's bookThe Way of Sanchin Kata: The Application of Power, and the two really should be used in conjunction.  The video greatly enhances the book and fills in some gaps that the text, by its very nature, could not confront.  In fact, I recommend starting with the video and then working backwards to the book, as the basics are easiest to learn in a visual format while the book goes into more depth and provides a wider array of structure tests.As a final note, the production values in this video are excellent, and the menu is intuitive and easy to navigate.  In fact, it is broken down by body part, allowing viewers to rewatch the specific segments on which they have questions, such as the placement of the feet or the positioning of the arms.  Also, its length (one hour) is perfect.  Not too long to be cumbersome or overwhelming, as is the case with many martial arts videos, but long enough to cover the material in the appropriate depth.  All in all, I give this video my highest recommendation.
summary: A sure-fire way to increase the power of your techniques.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really wanted to like this DVD.  It's on a topic that I have a lot of interest in.  But it wasn't as good as I thought it would be given all the reviews of it that I read. Not that it was bad, but I think I got my expectations up a bit too high.I am also a GoJu Ryu black belt and have been studying martial arts of several types since the late '70s.  Sanchin kata is the foundation of my primary style.Yes, there were some very detailed explanations of what to do.  What I found somewhat lacking were explanations of why to do it the way that was being shown.For example, there was a lot of detail presented about how to place the feet in the Sanchin stance.  But I found the explanation less than compelling that part of the reason for this placement was so that the middle toe of the foot was pointing straight forward, thus giving the stance is characteristic pigeon-toed appearance and feel.There was no real "why" given as far as "why" it might be important to have the middle toe pointing straight forward (or why it would have to be exactly that position as opposed to slight variations on the angle).  Saying that this position actually has the foot pointing forward, even though it feels pigeon-toed, is not really an explanation in my view.And perhaps my disappointment in this sort of explanation is partly due to my having my own ideas about why the stance is the way that it is. In my mind, this has a lot to do with wrapping the musculature around the leg bones to take the slack out of the system and thus better supporting the skeletal structure. The position also allows for the knees to track inward over the toes which both helps protect the groin and allows the practitioner to sit into the inguinal groove of the hips (what in Chinese martial arts is referred to as sinking into the "kua"). The pigeon-toed nature of the stance, combined with the muscle wrapping, also provides some outward pressure at the heels.  The combination of all of these factors creates an extremely stable and mobile stance (mobile in any direction) for moving on what may be at times a very unstable or uncertain surface.The reality is, for me, that the degree of angle in the pigeon-toed positioning of the feet is related to the height of the practitioner and the length of their leg bones and leg muscles relative to each other.  A taller, lankier person may need to have a more "severe" pigeon-toed position in their feet to accomplish the overall goal than a shorter more stout person would.I couldn't find anything in the explanation given that either helped me to better support my own ideas about the stance, or that gave me enough to challenge my own ideas about why the stance is the way that it is.This is what I felt about many of the explanations given in the presentation for other details of the form.  Not that I saw anything that was necessarily wrong.  The explanations just didn't go as deep as I was hoping they might given all the great reviews that I read.Again, not that the DVD is bad.  It's actually very well done.  The productions values are very good.  And the information would be very helpful to those trying to get started with Sanchin kata.I did think that Sensei Wilder spent a little too much time at the beginning of the DVD railing against the idea of people being able to learn martial arts from a DVD (a position that I always find a little ironic coming from folks who are selling martial arts DVDs).  Personally, I think it's the quality of instruction that's important, not the media by which the instruction is delivered.So overall, good but not as great as I was hoping for.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Sensei Kris Wilder has done a marvelous job presenting the all-important intricacies of the sanchin kata in this highly informative DVD. The production values are of high quality, to include beautifully filmed footage outside where the kata is performed on forest paths and even on a rocky creek bed, to the excellent camera work in the studio that allows the viewer to see the presentation from all angles.The sensei breaks down the kata by body part, beginning at the feet and progressing up to the head, explaining in rich detail the dos and don't of each that will help you bring out the best in your sanchin form and, in time, your other kata, your basic technique, and even your sparring.Take it from a martial artist who has been training since 1965, this information -crammed DVD is a winner.Loren W. Christensen, author of dozens of books on the martial arts and seven instructional DVDs.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Most of the instruction, and most of the DVD, is about the Sanchin stance and not the kata itself. This is the very best part of the DVD and merits a 5 star plus rating. There is a detailed description of the positioning of the feet, knees, hips, spine, arms and breathing technique in the Sanchin stance. This is the type of detailed technical analysis that the Japanese style karate senseis do very well. Since this kata is really about mastering a fundamental stance and not about the detailed applications, this is exactly the emphasis needed in this DVD.Sanchin is a critical foundation kata that is widely practices in many Okinawan, Japanese and Chinese martial arts. It is a major form used in Goju Ryu karate, Uechi Ryu karate, Shotokan karate, White Crane Kungfu and Five Ancestor's kung fu among others.The Sanchin kata is a very unusual form. Most katas are primarily about technique and martial arts applications. They are done quickly, with power and focus on learning specific attacks and defense.Sanchin, on the other hand, is about minimal self defense technique and is about devloping maximum power and chi. It is done slowly and is used to develop powerful roots while building a stable moving stance that forms the basis for exceptional power. It is a very short form with only a few techniques. Simple punches mostly. It is all about developing power that will be utilized in the techniques that make up the other katas in the martial arts. In Chinese martial arts terminology, this form is about the intersection of internal chi based arts and the external muscle and strength based martial arts.Just like the Sanchin Kata, this DVD is relatively short. It is about 55 minutes long.It opens with a voice over lecture on the relationship between a teacher and student while doing a demo of Sanchin outdoors in a wooded area. There is a discussion of why, historically, teachers withheld knowledge from students and when they trusted them enough to explain what was really going on in the katas. It goes on to a demonstration of the kata in a dojo setting.The reason I rate this as 4 star and not 5 star is that the DVD is relatively short. It is taught only from the perspective of the Goju Ryu version of the form. That is OK. But it would have been very interesting to hear more about the different variations of Sanchin as practives in the other Chinese, Okinawan and Japanese styles.If you are learning and practicing the Sanchin kata, then you really want to get this DVD and watch it over and over again to learn the subtleties of the Sanchin stance. The fact that the variation of the kata that you are practicing might be different than this verion in some details does not matter. The Sanchin kata is all about mastering the Sanchin stance and this DVD will help you learn the fine points of the stance.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Well I guess I should start off by stating that this DVD is remarkable by itself, but as good as it is, it is even better if used in conjunction withThe Way of Sanchin Kata: The Application of Poweralso by Sensei Kris Wilder. Both of which I highly recommend that you purchase and study if you truly desire to improve your skills as a martial artist.Sensei Wilder's DVD covers all aspects of executing not only the Sanchin Kata correctly, but the way he presents the material, everything he teaches could easily be applied to other katas as well and not just the Sanchin Kata, of which there seems to be several different versions or variations. Rather than teaching "his" was of executing the kata from an external perspective (technique), Sensei Wilder teaches you the more important internal workings (primciples) of the kata, which should be all the same regardless of what the external technique is, and this is the hallmark of a master!I have often said that the one true key to finding a true martial arts master is to find one who focuses more on the principles behind a technique rather than focusing too much on the technique itself, and Sensei Wilder definitely fits that description.Shawn KovacichCreator of numerous books and DVD's.
summary: A Literal Cornucopia of Martial Arts Knowledge Contained In This DVD
Title: N/A

reviewText: This video presents a nearly complete (or at least more complete than any other Sanchin references that I have found) analysis of the structure and body mechanics that make the Sanchin kata one of the most important and practiced karate kata.  The viewer will enhance their understanding of Sanchin through great discussions and demonstrations of body mechanics.  Through his analysis, Kris Wilder presents many of the  "whys" behind the structure.  Wilder begins with the basic Sanchin-dachi stance and works through the feet, angles, lower legs, hips, etc.... all the way up to the head and out to the hands.The lessons presented by Sensei Wilder can be applied to many styles of martial arts, not just Goju-ryu, and not just karate.  I find some of the fundamental structure and body mechanics commentary to be applicable to some of the classical chinese martial arts such as tai chi and hsing-i.One of the other many benefits of the DVD is the duration.  At 60 minutes long, I find this DVD to be easily watched and referenced.  Many of YMAA publications are several hours in length and can be a burden to study because of the depth and content.  Here, Wilder presents all necessary information in a format that could easily be incorporated into a presentation and study during dojo/class hours.  Oddly enough, as another reviewer has mentioned the DVD jacket mentions movement study of the "Cresent Step."  This discussion must not have made it through the editing process.
summary: This structure lesson is applicable to several styles.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As a martial artist who regularly attends his classes and keeps up with practice outside of the dojo, I look for instructional material filled with the best information available. Although i do not look primarily for special effects, beautiful setting etc. I do react to those.Watching this dvd i was totally surprised: the quality of the production is superb: from lighting to scenography to direction. Excellent!As others reviewers have pointed out, the dvd is a full dose of instruction, both philosophical and practical. The first part should be watched several  times by every martial artist, regardless of their discipline. It contains invaluable information about the kata.The second part contains detail instruction on how to execute the form. It's like being at the dojo with a very knowledgeable instructor who is constantly showing the correct stance, etc.In summary: whether you are a student enrolled in martial art school or a home-schooled student, there is a wealth of information that, because of the foundational material, should be on everybody 's shelf.
summary: All you need for an excellent execution of the kata
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have the book, I also have this DVD.  There is not much I can add to what other reveiwers have said except.  This is like being in a classroom.  Don't just sit and watch this dvd, get up and actually do the things Sensei Wilder is talking about.  If you do you should be able to re-create the sensations he is talking about.  This is a training and teaching dvd that is for the student.  Apply the principles to other katas you know and you will understand why Kris says that Sanchin is the hub of all katas.I have went so far as to compare Sanchin stance with the first stance or movements of the Sil Lim Tau form of Wing Chun.  Although similar and dissimilar they are both the building blocks of there respective systems.  I hope that Sensei Wilder will do the same with other forms in the future until then we will have to be content with Sanchin.Sanchin Kata DVD should be in your library for study and comparison at least three times a week.  Correctily practicing your form will increase the power of your techniques and improve your health.  I know this from expierience so should you.
summary: Just like being in a classroom....
Title: N/A

reviewText: Sanchin Kata Traditional Training for Karate Power by Kris Wilder could have been called Traditional Training for Martial Power.There is a great deal of instruction on the principles of structure. Mr. Wilder says that "form must follow function and the function must be clear." He does a great job of doing just that. Starting at the feet and working up the body to the kua, arms, back, spine and head;he clearly shows correct and incorrect position. I had a smile when he continued to correct the overly bend back leg of the student, as my own taiji teacher was working on that with me this week. Good alignment is key to any form.The filming of this DVD is clear, the studio set clean and easy to see the full body of the players. The outside venue where the form is demonstrated is quite beautiful and also shows the form being played on rocky ground, not just a flat dojo floor.I like the way the instructor used analogies to explain his thoughts: The Goldie Locks rule, not too much, not too little, just right. Not too much blocking, not too little power, just right in every sequence.He also talks about bringing rocks back from the moon. Some of the rocks brought back from the moon expeditions were put on immediate display so that people could wonder at them and learn about them. However some of the rocks were put away for a later date, when scientists are ready to reveal more of the secrets. Just like the katas, you are never ready to learn everything about them at first glance. (as in all other forms of martial arts). He also speaks somewhat about the history, in general of Sanchin Kata. He tells how it was used to protect the family and how, in order to be effective, not every secret was taught to every student. Only the worthy and trustworthy were shown, as it truly was a matter of life and death.This DVD was excellent for anyone looking to begin Karate training. Please note, however, there is no instruction in the particular form being show. The form is demonstrated and the structure of the stance is gone over in great detail. This makes the DVD most valuable.The only thing I would have liked to have explained is the heavy breathing that was done during the form. This is the exact opposite of our taiji forms, where the breath is silent, even to the player. I'm just curious. Another minor point is that "Crescent Step " in not mentioned in the DVD but it is mentioned on the jacket. Is this a moving step, as shown in the form demo or just the name of the stance?I would highly recommend this dvd to people looking to begin martial arts training. It shows the meat and potato of the form and not just the sizzle on the platter.
Title: N/A
